title-group.article-title: Modelling and experimental validation of dynamic characteristics of porous-walled air film for non-contact conveyor system

abstract.p: Air film conveyors equipped with porous pads have been developed to bring the liquid crystal display into a non-contact state during transportation process. In this study, a theoretical model of one porous-walled radial flow, considering the effects of velocity slip at the surface of the porous medium, is established within a representative region, and its validity is verified by vibrating a moveable plate close to the porous surface to conduct investigations on pressure dynamic response. Due to the air damping effects, an apparent pressure hysteresis is observed when the air film subjected to periodic sinusoidal squeeze, and particularly for a given gap thickness, the pressure show approximate proportion to the squeezing velocities. A slip coefficient valued 0.004 is determined and applied to the theoretical model to study the air damping characteristics. In accordance with the experimental results, it is found that the air damping is greatly affected by the region radius, but little by the supply flow rate. Also, it is confirmed that the velocity slip is capable of inhibiting the damping effect. Moreover, free-decay oscillation of a suspended workpiece is inspected. The results indicate that the oscillating amplitude continuously attenuates until the workpiece finally becomes stable, and any change to the region radius or the supply flow rate can exert direct or indirect impact on the decay speed.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
Workpieces are conventionally moved using rollers or vacuum chucks in the manufacturing process. Such contact methods are often accompanied by surface scratching and static electricity, thus easily result in trace and deformation to fragile semiconductor products during the course of conveying. In order to prevent contact between handling device and workpieces, many non-contact handling approaches, typically employing magnetic, electrostatic, near-field, vortex and aerodynamic levitation, have been proposed and have proven effective.1–3 Recently, in the production of liquid crystal display (LCD), manufacturers are turning to develop larger-sized glass substrates to improve production efficiencies and reduce costs, but, such glass substrates are very difficult to be handled by above methods. Accordingly, air tracks, with multiple orifices arranged at appropriate intervals, are used to realize non-contact levitation by supplying pressurized air through these orifices beneath the glass substrates.4,5 Chandra et al.6 presented a study on the load capacity and pressure distribution of the air film conveyor composed of aligned orifice restrictors. Their theoretical results showed that there exists a considerable pressure peak at the centre of each orifice, where a large deformation is easily caused to the flexible glass sheet. Besides, airflow ejected from the orifice will undoubtedly roll up a large amount of dust and deteriorate the ambient cleanliness. To avoid these problems, an alternative design is the usage of porous medium as a restrictor, which is capable of eliminating the pressure peak and also easing the stress concentration.7 A sketch of a partial porous air conveyor is shown in Figure 1. Lee and Lee8 constructed an airflow model between the LCD glass sheet and the conveyor surface with porous pads. They investigated the air film pressure distribution and found that the model can provide close approximations to the experimental data, but lack of a detailed description on the experimental procedure. Very recently, Amano et al.9 developed an air conveyor system involving alternately placed 19 mm square porous air supply and exhaust pads. Their numerical and experimental results indicate that a wavy deformation of the large-sized glass sheet is easily caused when quiescently supported by the air-pad system. Oiwa et al.10 also studied the deformation behaviour of glass sheets on aerostatic porous bearing guides, and found that it is closely associated with the air film boundary conditions. However, existing references stated above mainly focus on the air film pressure distribution or glass sheet deformation, either recognized as a form of static characteristics. During transportation, glass sheets are very likely to be unstable, and there is still a need to analyse the dynamic characteristics, which concerns the squeeze film that a fluid layer situated between surfaces approaching each other. A number of studies11–13 have demonstrated the squeeze film characteristics by mathematical modelling, making reasonable presumptions for boundary layers in the film. For those impermeable walls, the flow profile is generally considered to be a parabolic shape, but for the porous walls, it is suggested to take the existence of velocity slip into account.14,15 Sparrow et al.16 established a velocity slip involved model to discern the load-carrying capacity of the squeeze film as well as its thickness–time relation, with the Darcy’s law used to describe the relation of flow velocity versus pressure gradient throughout the porous medium. Our earlier research17 on the flow rate characteristics of porous medium reveals that a Forchheimer-extended regime must be applied when the flow rate becomes adequately large for higher accuracy, and therefore, the model needs to be reconstructed. Figure 1.
Schematic of a partial porous conveyor system.

In this study, we propose a theoretical model to characterize a one porous-walled radial flow, with the flow rate through the porous medium represented by the Forchheimer-extended equation. Dynamic characteristics of the air film are examined experimentally, and the effectiveness of the proposed model is verified by the comparison of the experimental and theoretical results.

sec.title: Theoretical model
sec.p: Consequently, Navier–Stokes equation in r-direction is simplified as the following form (1)-∂p∂r+μ∂2ur∂z2=0 where p is the pressure, μ the air viscosity and ur the flow velocity in r-direction.
On the other hand, Navier–Stokes equation in z-direction is simplified as below (2)μ∂2uz∂z2=0 where uz is the flow velocity in z-direction.

For the film region with one porous wall, considering a slip velocity at the porous surface, the following boundary condition is made16 (3){∂ur∂z=αKur,z=0;ur=0,z=h where K is the permeability coefficient, h the gap thickness and α the slip coefficient, which is a dimensionless constant that depends on the characteristics of the porous medium, but independent of the gap thickness and properties of the fluid.

Integrating equation (1) with respect to z, according to the boundary condition of equation (3), yields (4)ur=∂p∂rz22μ-∂p∂rhz2μ-zhKα∂p∂rz-∂p∂rh2μ+μhKα +Kα∂p∂rz-∂p∂rh2μ+μhKα For simplification, S is defined as (5)S=Kαh Substituting equation (5) into equation (4), the flow velocity in r-direction is thereby given by (6)ur=12μ∂p∂r(2z2-3zh+h21+S-(z-h)2) Flow velocity in z-direction is known as uz = ω0 (z = 0), and uz = dh/dt (z = h). Here, ω0 is the average flow velocity at the interface z = 0 and t the time. Integrating equation (3) with respect to z, the flow velocity in z-direction is thus expressed as (7)uz=zhdhdt-ω0hz+ω0 Continuity equation takes the form as (8)1r∂(prur)∂r+∂(puz)∂z+∂p∂t=0 Substituting equations (6) and (7) into equation (8), yields (9)∂p∂t=h212μ(2-1S+1)(pr∂p∂r+p∂2p∂r2+(∂p∂r)2) +ph(ω0-dhdt) For impermeable-walled film, using the no-slip condition that ur = 0 (z = 0) and ur = 0 (z = h), integrating equation (2) with respect to z, we obtain (10)ur=12μ∂p∂r(z2-hz) Integrating equation (3) with respect to z, with the boundary conditions that uz = 0 (z = 0) and uz = dh/dt (z = h), flow velocity in z-direction can be written as (11)uz=zhdhdt Substituting equations (10) and (11) into equation (8), yields (12)∂p∂t=h212μ(pr∂p∂r+p∂2p∂r2+(∂p∂r)2)+ph(ω0-dhdt) Both the wall and the air film are divided into n + 1 grids (Figure 3), denoted as A1[i] and A2[i] (i = 0–n), respectively. For any of the A1[i] (except the flange region), the Forchheimer-extended equation17 is applied to attain the flow rate through the porous medium, and thus the ω0 is calculated. A finite volume method (FVM) is used to solve equations (9) and (12) to gain the pressure status in each grid. It should be noted that when the radius becomes extremely small, p/r tends to infinity, causing these equations to be unsolvable. Additionally, to give an initial pressure for the calculation of pressure gradient, the following air state equation is specially used to characterize the status change in grid 0 (13)p0πr02h=m0RT0 where m0 is the air mass, r0 the radius, p0 the pressure and T0 the temperature. Figure 3.
Grid generation of the computational domain.
The following equation is derived by differentiating equation (13) (14)dp0dt=RT0πr02h(dm0dt)-p0hdhdt where dm0dt is the net mass flow rate passing through grid 0.

In particular, for grid 0, velocity slip is disregarded since its weak influence, hence (15)dm0dt=ω0·πr02·ρ-2πr0ρ·∫0hurdz Substitution of the expression of ur and equation (15) into equation (14) yields (16)dp0dt=RT0πr02h(ω0·πr02·ρ-2πr0ρ·h36·12μ∂p∂r)-p0hdhdt Each grid is firstly initialized with atmospheric pressure, and an iteration routine is applied to calculate the pressure distribution. If the clearance is variable, dh/dt should also be taken into account. Then, the pressure of grid 0 is computed using equation (16), while the pressures of grid 1 − n are computed using equations (9) and (12). After every iteration cycle, the calculated pressure data are updated and saved at regular intervals, and also checked simultaneously to confirm whether it converges or not. If not, relevant parameter, such as the calculation step or grid width, must be modified to resume the calculation until the number of iterations reaches the set value. Figure 4 represents the algorithm for calculating the pressure distribution. Figure 4.
Algorithm for calculating the air film pressure distribution.

sec.title: Dynamic pressure response
sec.p: Supposing a large-sized glass sheet transferred along several air tracks in a production line, it is susceptible to external disturbances and very likely to exhibit an oscillation behaviour that concerns the dynamic characteristics of the air film. In this section, dynamic pressure response is inspected by vibrating a workpiece at various frequencies to squeeze the air film. The experimental work and results may help us better understand the dynamic characteristics.

sec.title: Experimental rig
sec.p:
A sketch of the apparatus used for pressure response measurement is shown in Figure 5. An L-type table, installed on a sliding track, is connected to a wall by a spring, and a motor with an eccentric nut equipped at the shaft is fixed on the table. When the motor rotates at a certain frequency, the table vibrates along the sliding track at the same frequency. The vibration amplitude and frequency can be varied by adjusting the position of the nut as well as the rotating velocity. The porous pad employed in the experiment was fabricated by sintering SUS316L powder into a plate shape under a temperature above 1000 ℃. During the sintering process, complicated flow paths were formed by the interconnected and dead-end pores, as shown in the microscope photograph of the porous surface (Figure 5). Dimensions and specifications of the porous pad are tabulated in Table 1. A cylindrical rubber is used to seal the porous pad in a metal sleeve, which is fixed to be in parallel with the table by the following steps. 1. Erect the whole apparatus and place the metal sleeve on the table. Then, set down three pins through the pin clamps, ensuring that their tips touch the top of the metal sleeve. 2. Turn the pin clamps until the pins are held tightly, and then preload the spring to make the metal sleeve to be pulled upward via a ball-hinge connection. 3. Revert the whole apparatus to horizontal position, and make use of a laser sensor (LK-30, KEYENCE Co., Ltd) to detect the movement of the table. Two differential pressure sensors (PA-100, Copal Electronics Co., Japan), with a measuring range 0–2 kPa and a response time of 5 ms, are positioned on the table to measure the pressure change through pressure taps, denoted as pr0 (r = 0 mm) and pr10 (r = 10 mm). In this way, pressure response of the air film, along with the gap thickness, becomes measureable. Figure 5.
Experimental apparatus for dynamic pressure response.
Table 1.
Dimensions and specifications of the porous pad.
Diameter 20 mm
Thickness 3 mm
Porosity 0.434
Permeability coefficient 4.69 × 10−12 m2
Inertia coefficient 0.76

Due to the fact that the supply pressure for practical non-contact conveyor system is something less than 10 kPa, it is difficult to maintain such a low pressure accurately during experimental process. Moreover, the paired data of supply pressure and flow rate are also desired for further evaluation of the proposed model. In view of these cases, a constant mass flow rate condition is produced by providing a choked flow and applied to all experiments in this study. Air supply circuit is shown in Figure 5. Compressed air is supplied and regulated to an appropriate pressure. A thermal−type flow meter is installed to guarantee an unchangeable flow rate of 8.89 × 10−5 kg/s during the experimental process, and a buffer tank with a volume of 5 L is placed to stabilize the supply pressure.

sec.title: Results of pressure response
sec.p:
Variation of the gap thickness is limited within a range from 150 to 400 µm that commonly encountered in industrial conveying process. Pressure responses measured at the frequencies of 15 Hz and 30 Hz are shown in Figure 6(a) and (c). When the gap thickness repeats an approximately sinusoidal movement, the film pressure varies correspondingly, especially prominent at small thickness. It is also found that the pressure response is quite fast, consistent with the vibration movement without apparent delay. A presentation of the experimental data in the form of the pressure versus gap thickness is shown in Figure 6(b) and (d). These figures indicate that there exists an obvious pressure hysteresis between the forth and back stroke, resulting from the squeeze film effect. To be exact, when the table moves close to the porous surface, squeezed air tends to flow through the gap into atmosphere but hampered due to the viscous effect at the interface, leading to a pressure increase in comparison with that of the steady state. And also, some energy dissipates in the form of heat as the airflow rub against the wall. The comparison of Figure 6(b) and (d) implies that the pressure hysteresis becomes more clear when raising the response frequency. In addition, simply for the steady state, one can imagine that the film pressure shows a trend of monotonic decreasing with the change of gap thickness. Therefore, two aspects, spring effect and damping effect, are considered to contribute to the pressure change at any position. The spring effect corresponds to such a case that the pressure varies with the gap thickness at a given flow rate. But in this study, it is not made deep discussions, and we mainly focus on the damping effect that regards the dynamic characteristics. Figure 6.
(a) Gap thickness, pressure versus time (15 Hz); (b) pressure versus gap thickness (15 Hz); (c) gap thickness, pressure versus time (30 Hz); and (d) pressure versus gap thickness (30 Hz).

sec.title: Analysis of air damping effects
sec.p:
With the apparatus shown in Figure 5, some other operations are performed as follows: (a) cut the spring connection between the L-type table and the wall; (b) hold the table to move it back and forth to squeeze the air film while keeping the motor rotating. By this means, the table remains vibrating along the sliding track while moving back and forth, thus it passes through the same position at different velocities time after time. A large amount of the experimental data of air film pressure and gap thickness is recorded. The motion velocity is derived by differentiating the gap thickness with respect to the time, and denoted as dh/dt. It is worth mentioning that the motion velocity is negative if the table moving towards the porous surface, positive if the table leaving the porous surface. The data with gap thickness of 150, 180, 210, 240, 270 and 300 µm are extracted and organized into a representation of pressure plotted against velocity under different film thickness, as emerged in Figure 7(a) and (b). Observation discloses that there exists an approximately linear relation between the two at a certain film thickness. A least-square straight line is passed through the experimental data, with the absolute value of the slope representing the damping coefficient per unit area and denoted as Cp. In particular, intercept of the fitting curve on vertical axis depicts the pressure under steady state. Figure 7.
(a) Pressure versus velocity at different gap thickness (r = 0 mm); (b) pressure versus velocity at different gap thickness (r = 10 mm).

Recall that the porous pad is sealed in a metal sleeve by a cylindrical rubber, so, it is quite common for the existence of a step between the porous and flange surface. A laser sensor was used to detect the step for more than 10 different locations, and an average step of 6.3 µm is procured and taken into consideration in the calculation. Furthermore, the slip coefficient, which plays an important role in the description of velocity profile, should be ascertained in advance. Beavers and Joseph18 determined the slip coefficient by carrying out simultaneous measurements of the flow rate through a long porous block and also through a small uniform gap immediately above the block. However, this approach does not work for the present porous pad because its lateral surface is impermeable. Instead, the slip coefficient is identified by a trial-and-error method. That is, adjusting the slip coefficient to achieve an agreement of the experimental and calculated results under the steady state. With a value of 0.004, as shown in Figure 8, an error less than 3% is estimated by a root-sum-square method, showing that the chosen slip coefficient makes sense and can afford sufficient accuracy for the calculation. Figure 8.
Air film pressure versus gap thickness (α = 0.004).

Damping coefficient per unit area Cp versus gap thickness is displayed in Figure 9(a) and (b). The most striking feature is that Cp changes little in despite of a shift in the flow rate from 8.89 × 10− 5 to 7.31 × 10−5 kg/s, exposing that Cp hardly affected by the supply flow rate. But, it shows a remarkable variation as the region radius varies. Reduction in the region radius is considered to make the fluid motion subjected to a weaker viscous drag, which, in turn, weakens the squeeze film effect. Moreover, the calculated results, based on the proposed theoretical model, are confirmed to provide close approximations with the experimental data. To study the influence from velocity slip, an extra calculation is conducted for no-slip case (), with the upstream pressure the same as one of the slip case (curve (—)). Quite clearly, the Cp without considering the velocity slip appears to be larger. For the slip case, airflow induces a horizontal component immediately below the interface, so, it can be equivalently regarded that the introduction of the velocity slip leads to an increase in the porous resistance, which therefore causes a reduction in the flow rate. Nevertheless, as was verified, the supply flow rate produces little effect on Cp, and hereby, the larger Cp for the no-slip case naturally reveals that the velocity slip phenomenon can restrain the damping effect to a certain extent. Figure 9.
(a) Damping coefficient per unit area versus gap thickness (r = 0 mm); (b) damping coefficient per unit area versus gap thickness (r = 10 mm).

sec.title: Free-decay oscillation
sec.p: In this section, dynamic characteristics of the air film are further perceived by inspecting the free-decay oscillation of a suspended workpiece. The experimental data are contrasted with the calculated results to validate the efficiency of the proposed model.

sec.title: Experimental apparatus
sec.p:
A schematic diagram of the apparatus for free-decay oscillation measurement is shown in Figure 10. The metal sleeve used earlier, with the porous pad enclosed, is installed on a stationary table with the surface facing upwards. It is worth noting that two air circuits exist, one for air supply, and the other for producing an airflow pulse disturbance by means of a nozzle. For the air supply, compressed air is regulated, and a choked flow through the orifice is maintained. Before the experiment, the stationary table is adjusted to be in a horizontal posture by four adjustable screws, with a spirit level placed on the surface for confirmation. A workpiece is then levitated upon the air film, and three columns are set to prevent it from slipping away. Because the lateral surface of the column is extremely smooth, even more importantly, by a line contact, so the friction between the workpiece and the columns can be ignored. Flying height of the workpiece is recorded by a laser sensor (LK-30, Keyence Co., Japan), and the upstream pressure of the porous pad is measured by a differential pressure transducer (KL17, Nagano Keiki Co., Japan), which has a measuring range 0–10 kPa. The free-decay oscillation is measured as follows. (1) Maintain a constant flow rate and suspend the workpiece on the air film. (2) Open the on–off valve to start a pulse disturbance (for 5 ms), thus the workpiece follows a free-decay oscillation. (3) Acquire the experimental data by a 16 bit A/D board with a sampling time of 0.5 ms until the workpiece recovers to stable status. Figure 10.
Experimental setup for free-decay oscillation.

sec.title: Experimental results and discussions
sec.p: Consider a workpiece supported by the air film, as shown in Figure 2. Two forces are present, a lift force Fl, due to the film pressure, and the gravity Mg. The lift force is calculated by integrating the pressure with respect to the radius and expressed as (17)Fl=p0πr02+∑i=1n2πriΔrpi where pi is the pressure of grid i, ri the radius and Δr the grid width.

The equation describing the motion of the workpiece is given by (18)Md2hdt2=Fl-Mg Under a constant supply flow rate, oscillation of the workpiece generally makes for a fluctuation to the upstream pressure, especially visible for those loose porous medium that has a large permeability coefficient. A correct way to conduct the iterative calculation is to measure the actual upstream pressure data and apply them into the model. Figure 11(a) and (b) illustrates a contrast of the calculated and experimental results under different supply flow rate, region radius and load. The workpiece is forced to move downwards when imposed by the pulse disturbance, and oscillates near the equilibrium position due to the inertia effect. The amplitude continuously attenuates until it finally becomes stable. Note that the action point by pulse disturbance may deviate from the centre of the workpiece, easily conducing to an inaccurate result during the first few cycles. Therefore, the analytical calculation is conducted after several periods, particularly from a valley bottom of the oscillating curve where the velocity is zero. The predicted results are found to be in acceptable accordance with the experimental data points on the whole, despite a somewhat different oscillating phase. Figure 11.
(a) Free-decay vibration (R2 = 20 mm); (b) free-decay vibration (R2 = 27.5 mm).

Further observations in Figure 11(a) and (b) show that the increase in region radius is accompanied by an evident acceleration in the oscillating decay speed. But for some other influencing factors, for example, the variation of the load or the supply flow rate, it is difficult to make a judgement only from these figures. A convenient way to depict the damping effect is to measure the rate of decay of free oscillations. Hence, a term called logarithmic decrement, defined as the natural logarithm of the ratio of two successive amplitudes, is introduced. Three parameters, the flow rate, region radius and load, are initially set to 9.88 × 10−5 kg/s, 17 mm and 12.8 g, respectively. Investigations on the decay speed are performed by altering one of the three while the other two kept at the initial value, with the pulse velocity set to −0.02 m/s all along. A non-dimensional transformation of the x-coordinate is made in Figure 12 for easy observation, with M*, G* and R2*, respectively, denoting the ratio of each parameter to its initial value. It is known that the change of the load little influences the logarithmic decrement, while an increase in the supply flow rate lead to a decrease in the logarithmic decrement. In fact, any alterations to either the load mass or the supply flow rate naturally causes changes to the floating height, which, as was mentioned earlier, are proved to have impacts on the damping effect and thus easily conduce to misinterpretations. In the present case, the damping effect is seldom affected by the supply flow rate, and it is the changes in floating height exert influence on the oscillating decay speed. Besides, although an increase in the region radius brings about an increase to the flying height, the effect result from the variation of the region radius prevail over that from the flying height and become dominant. Figure 12.
Logarithmic decrement versus non-dimensionalized load, flow rate and region radius.

As a result, reduction in the supply flow rate indirectly enables a faster oscillating decay speed. However, lower flying height may face the risk of scratch on the glass surface, which should be counted carefully according to practical condition. On the other hand, when designing a conveyor track, raising the width of the track appropriately can restrain the unstable oscillation phenomenon, but if overly, large deformation to the glass substrate will be caused.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p:
This study provides an insight into the dynamic characteristics of one porous-walled air film. The results can be concluded as follows.
A theoretical model of the radial flow with one porous wall, considering a velocity slip boundary, is established within a representative region, and solved by a FVM method to obtain the pressure distribution.
Pressure response of the squeezed film is investigated by vibrating a moveable plate close to the porous surface, and it is found that there exists a pressure hysteresis, which becomes apparent when raising the vibrating frequency. In addition, at a certain gap thickness, the pressure is approximately proportional to the squeezing velocity, and the slope, representing the damping coefficient per unit area, varies as the change of the gap thickness.
The slip coefficient is determined as a value of 0.004 by a trial-and-error method, and applied to the proposed theoretical model. Experimental and theoretical results confirm that: (a) supply flow rate little affects the damping effect; (b) region radius impacts the damping effect greatly; and (c) velocity slip is capable of restraining the damping effect to a certain extent.
Free-decay oscillation of a workpiece suspended on the air film is inspected experimentally. The results indicate that the proposed model is reasonable for characterizing the air film dynamic characteristics. Furthermore, analysis shows that appropriately increasing the width of the track or decreasing the supply flow rate can accelerate the oscillation decay. But if overly, some other practical problems may be caused.
